title: Alec Baldwin is hustled out of hundreds of dollars in infamous Statue of Liberty tour scam
text:
Alec Baldwin's family trip to see the Statue of Liberty turned into a painful crash course in New York City street smarts over the weekend.

The 61-year-old star thought he was buying Statue of Liberty tour tickets for himself, his wife, Hilaria, and their four youngest children - daughter Carmen and sons Rafael, Leonardo, and baby Romeo when they arrived in Battery Park in downtown Manhattan.

But he was shocked to realized tickets - which he shelled out $40 each for - were actually for a three-hour shuttle bus trip to New Jersey.

'I kid you not. We paid. Then we read the tickets. NO [ONE] EVER MENTIONED NEW F***ING JERSEY!!!' Baldwin wrote in an Instagram post about the debacle.

'This is a scam,' added the '30 Rock' star, who has lived in the Big Apple for many years.

He added: 'Take the SI Ferry. It’s the best ride in NY.'

The Baldwin clan snapped a photo, minus 11-month-old Romeo- from the deck a Staten Island Ferry instead

Baldwin posted a picture of the phony tickets on Instagram after realizing the passes were actually for a shuttle ride to New Jersey

It's a bit of a wonder a long-timer New Yorker like Baldwin would fall for such a cliche tourist con job.

Manhattan Battery Park hustlers have been tricking out-of-town visitors into buying sham tour tickets for decades.

NY’s Department of Transportation warns that the 'one hour tour' Baldwin bought tickets for would have first involved a three-hour coach ride through the Holland Tunnel to Liberty State Park in Jersey City, the NY Post reported.

Once there, they would board a boat that is NOT allowed to let tourists off at the Statue of Liberty's island in New York Harbor.

Hollywood A-lister Alec Baldwin and his wife Hilaria were tricked into buying bogus Statue of Liberty tour tickets (file image)

Large signs around Battery Park warn tourists that unofficial vendors are not authorized to sell tickets for to the Statue of Liberty.

The $40 Baldwin paid per ticket is also far more than the $18.50 charged by Statue Cruises - the company that has an exclusive contract with the National Park Service to take people to Liberty Island.

Luckily, Baldwin and his family made the best of the bad situation by jumping on the Staten Island - which is free.

Hilaria posted a photo of the Baldwin clan - minus 11-month old Romeo - catching the famed Staten Island ferry, which also offers great views of the 305-foot statue.

'We didn’t want to bring Romeo on the deck because it was so windy,' Hilaria wrote.

Baldwin and his family intended to catch close-up glimpses of Lady Liberty, but accidentally spent $40 per ticket on passes that turned out for a shuttle bus trip to New Jersey
description: Hollywood actor Alec Baldwin and his family were tricked into buying bogus Statue of Liberty tour tickets on Sunday. He posted a photo of the phony passes on Instagram.
